WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. Jane Warner
Address: Estherville, Sask.
Birthplace: Ireland

1. INTERCUTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in western Canada? 1912
Where did you set up housekeeping? Moose Range
Where had you been living before that? Elmworth, Man.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4
How far was it to your nearest store? 6 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Very few
tea sugar, flour, cereal, dried fruit salt pepper & spices

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Quaker
In what quantities did you buy it? 98 lb. bags
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? about $2.00
How much did you use graham flour? never
Whole wheat flour? rarely
Was flour milled locally? yes How far away was it that year? 1912
That was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 65¢
What other grain products did you use? cracked wheat
Cornmeal? Whole wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? yes
How did you grind it? with cracker
1. INTERESTING FACTS

What year did you start homesteading in eastern Canada? 1912
Where did you set up housekeeping? Alberta, Canada
How far had you been living before that? North Dakota, USA
For how many years did you live there? 6 months
How far was it to your nearest store? 5 miles
How often could a visit by mail to the store once a week?
What crops did you usually grow in those earliest years? Very few
Sugar stories, cereals, dried fruit, salted peppers

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Quaker
In what quantities did you buy it? 98 lbs. 4 eggs
Was this usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $0.80
How much did you make flour? None
What flour mills locally? None
Was flour milled locally? Yes
Was this the price for a ton? $1.00
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, oatmeal
Cornmeal? Yes
Other? None
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? With a millstone
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 10 lbs. 50 cts. or 1 cent.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 50 cts.
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Best.
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb.
At what price? 75 cts.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From cows.
Butter? Cream. Eggs? Hen's eggs.
What was the price of butter? 12 cts. of eggs? 8 to 10.
Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.
Did you make butter? Yes.
What kind of cheese? Cream.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork, Beef & Venison.
How did you get fresh meat? Raise it.
How often did you get fresh meat? Annually.
How did you preserve meat? Dry, Cured & Brine.
Has there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.
If so what year was it organized?
Did you use game? Yes.
What kinds? Prairie chicken, Pheasant, Wild duck.
For how long? As long as we could get them.
What part did fish play in the family diet? A little.
Has the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.
Kinds? Walleye, Jack, Herring, Pickerel.
3. SUGAR AND STARCH

In what quantity did you buy? (Will answer) 10 lbs. for the 25¢.

That was the price for a ton your stock of white sugar? $2.00.

That brand of flour was worth $1.75 on 32¢.

That size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lbs. 10¢.

At what price? 25¢.

6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon. At what price? 40¢.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Medium.

Price? ................. What other beverages were used? None.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 50¢.

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from? Grocer.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of: 1913.

Potatoes, Cabbage, Carrots, Onions, Turnips, Beets.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 5 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? In bulk.

What weight? 25 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? 10 lbs.

What was the price of prunes? 12½¢ lb.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.

Peas? Corn? Beans? Saskatoons?

Other foods? Blueberries & Rhubarb.

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1913.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1913.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1912.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes.

To what extent? Whatever we produce.

Did you make your own vinegar? Yes.

never
